parameters: Do you have your notebook and pen ready?
We're going to learn our second set of Hiragana
characters. There's 5 new characters to learn in this
I will go through each character individually and
teach you how to write it and pronounce it.
At the end of this chapter, we'll have a quiz, so
The characters we are learning in this lesson are
ka, ki, ku, ke and ko. Notice how these are similar
to our vowel sounds? You pronounce these syllables
the same way, only with a hard 'k' in front.
I'll pronounce each one for you as we go so you get
These characters are very commonly used in Japanese.
Since each character represents a syllable instead of
a single letter, you can form full Japanese words
quite quickly. Here's our first new character.
It's a consonant followed by a vowel, and makes up a
Practice writing the character now. Some tips:
You should draw the character in 3 separate strokes.
Pay careful attention to how the lines tilt.
Make sure to place the 3rd stroke in the right place.
Get ready for the next character!
It's a consonant followed by a vowel, and makes up a
Practice writing the character now. Some tips:
Depending on the font or script, it can be written in 3
or 4 strokes. The tail can be split into 2 strokes in
some fonts. Use the animated example as best practice.
Get ready for the next character!
It's a consonant followed by a vowel, and makes up a
Practice writing the character now. Some tips:
It's written in just one stroke.
The upper and lower half are the same length.
Get ready for the next character!
It's a consonant followed by a vowel, and makes up a
Practice writing the character now. Some tips:
The 3rd stroke is longer than the 1st. Be sure to
curve the 3rd stroke as it finishes.
Get ready for the next character!
It's a consonant followed by a vowel, and makes up a
Practice writing the character now. Some tips:
Make this character with just 2 strokes.
That's it! We've finished this set of Hiragana.

interesting tidbit you should know. What would you

You'd say I was crazy, right? Well, I'll show you
what I mean! Firstly, would you like to save your
There's an amazing feature of the Hiragana writing
little symbols that look like the above image.
What are these little characters used for?
Well, when you add them to another Hiragana character,
you can make an entirely new sound.
Take か and add the dakuten marks.
When you see Hiragana you already know with the
dakuten symbol attached, you'll know that you need
to pronounce it a bit differently.
Any Hiragana that starts with a 'k' will turn into
a syllable starting with 'g'. The 'g' sound is always
pronunced as a hard 'g'. Don't be tempted to pronounce
I'll go through our 5 new characters and show you
what they become when you add dakuten.
Write か　as normal, then add your dakuten marks in
the position shown in the image above.
Do you want me to pronounce it again?
Practice writing が in your notebook now.
Write き　as normal, then add your dakuten marks in
the position shown in the image above.
Do you want me to pronounce it again?
Practice writing ぎ in your notebook now.
Write く　as normal, then add your dakuten marks in
the position shown in the image above.
Do you want me to pronounce it again?
Practice writing ぐ in your notebook now.
Write け　as normal, then add your dakuten marks in
the position shown in the image above.
Do you want me to pronounce it again?
Practice writing げ in your notebook now.
Write こ as normal, then add your dakuten marks in
the position shown in the image above.
Do you want me to pronounce it again?
Practice writing ご in your notebook now.
We've now finished this set! Many Hiragana characters
can have dakuten attached to them, but not all of them.
As we learn more characters, I'll teach you which ones
